questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN)?

choices.text: It is primarily associated with bacterial infection.
HPV infection is not associated with VIN.
>50% of cases progress into vulvar cancer.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Smoking is an etiological factor.

 

Explanation:

 

Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN):

 

Etiology
  • HPV infection (HPV DNA found in 80% VIN lesions) (Option C)

→ Most common serotype - HPV 16

  • Other STDs - HSV, HIV
  • Cigarette smoking (Option B)
  • Immunosuppression
  • Lichen sclerosus or other chronic dermatological conditions

Classification
  • Vulvar LSIL: Self-limited, not precancerous
  • Vulvar HSIL (formerly called Usual VIN): Multicentric and multifocal disease
  • Differentiated VIN: Precursor to most vulvar SCC

Clinical features
  • The majority of patients are asymptomatic
  • Non-specific symptoms like pruritus, burning and pain are seen in some patients.

HSIL= high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; LSIL= low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

 

Incorrect options:

 

Option A: VIN is more closely related to viral infections, particularly human papillomavirus (HPV), rather than bacterial infections.

 

Option D: Majority of VIN patients recover spontaneously. Only 10% of patients progress into vulvar carcinoma.

questions.text: A 68 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a lump in the vulvar area. On examination, a lesion is noted on the labia majora. A biopsy of the lesion confirms vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is not a risk factor for vulvar carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B)Vulvar hamartoma

 

Explanation:

 

Vulvar Hamartoma:

  • A vulvar hamartoma is a benign tumor-like growth that occurs on the vulva, which is the external part of the female genitalia.
  • Hamartomas are made up of an abnormal mixture of tissue types that are normally found in the area but are disorganized and overgrown.


 

Risk factors:

HPV infection:(Option C)

  • The most significant risk factor for vulvar carcinoma is infection with Human papilloma Virus (HPV), particularly high-risk serotypes such as HPV 16 & 18 (option C).
  • 50-75% of invasive vulvar cancers are associated with high risk HPV infections.

Smoking:(Option A)

  • Women who smoke and have a history of HPV infection have a 35 fold greater risk of developing vulvar cancer.

Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia:

  • VIN is a precancerous condition, of which 10% of cases progress into Vulvar cancer

Chronic Immunosuppression:

  • HIV infection and organ transplantation.

Chronic dermatological conditions: (Option D)

  • Lichen sclerosus:Differentiated VIN is a precursor to keratinizing squamous cellcarcinoma and is strongly associated with lichen sclerosus.
  • Lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that causes itchy white patches on the genitals or other parts of the body

questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is most commonly associated with lichen sclerosus and typically occurs in postmenopausal women?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Keratinizing carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Vulvar carcinoma:

  • Vulvar carcinoma constitutes 6% of all gynecological tumors.
  • The average age of diagnosis is 65 years.(50-70 years)
  • The most common subtype of Vulvar carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma followed by melanoma.

 

Subtypes of Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (vSCC):

 

 

Warty/Basaloid vSCC

Keratinizing vSCC

Age group

Seen in younger women

Seen in older women

Risk factors

HPV infection (16 & 18),
Smoking,
Immunosuppression

Chronic dermatological conditions such as lichen sclerosus

Association with

Usual Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (HSIL)

P53 mutant differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia

Lesion

Multifocal

Unifocal

Prognosis

Better

Worse

questions.text: A 68 y/o female presents with a vulvar lesion on her labia majora. It measures 0.8 cm and has been present for several weeks. She reports persistent itching. What is the MOST appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Excisional biopsy

 

Explanation:

In the above scenario, in a post-menopausal woman, a vulvar lesion on the labia with persistent itching is most likely to be Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the vulva 

which is confirmed after biopsy.

 

 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the vulva

Site
  • Labia majora is the most common (60%).
  • Clitoris 2nd most common (15%).
  • Most common in 50-70 years age group

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth.

Symptom
  • Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain.

Spread
  • Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth. (Option C)
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size. (Option D)
  • Wedge biopsy.
  • Keyes punch biopsy.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes.

 

Vulvoscopy (Option A) is Limited to visual assessment; does not provide a definitive diagnosis.


Colposcopy (Option B) A valuable tool for visualizing and identifying suspicious areas for biopsy. However, it is not a diagnostic procedure on its own.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication of sentinel lymph node biopsy in vulvar cancer?

choices.text: Tumor is located on the labia majora.
Tumor is smaller than 4 cm in diameter.
Tumor invades > 1 mm into the stroma.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clinically suspicious groin lymph nodes.

 

Explanation:

Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB):

  • The sentinel lymph node is the first to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumour.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy involves inguinofemoral nodes (Superficial inguinal lymph nodes) using Technetium 99 or isosulphan blue dye.
  • Positive sentinel node: Radical lymphadenectomy.
  • Negative sentinel node: Only vulvectomy needed.
  • B/l inguinofemoral nodes are dissected for SLNB (if mass lies within 2 cm of the midline)

 

Prognostic significance:

  • Without groin node metastasis: >90% 5-year survival rate.
  • With groin node metastasis: 50% 5-year survival rate.

 

Indications of SLNB:

  • Unifocal tumors confined to the vulva.
  • Tumors <4 cm in diameter.
  • Stromal invasion >1 mm. (Option C)
  • Clinically and radiologically negative groin nodes.

Contraindication of SLNB:

  • SLNB is not performed if there is clinical suspicion of groin node metastasis because the goal of SLNB is to determine if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes. If there is already clinical suspicion of metastasis, a more extensive inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is typically performed.

Options A and B: The decision to perform SLNB is based on factors such as tumor location, size, invasion depth, and clinical suspicion of lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, fixed, non-tender, lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 cm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage IIIA

 

Explanation:

 

The patient in this scenario has a T2 tumor (>2 cm in size) with the involvement of two inguinal lymph nodes (N2a). According to the FIGO staging for invasive vulvar cancer, this clinical presentation corresponds to Stage IIIA.

 

Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A)

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B)

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C)

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D)

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

Regional LN refers to inguinal and femoral lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 68y/o woman presents with a 3 cm vulvar lesion. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a depth of invasion of 1.5 mm. Her inguinal lymph nodes are clinically negative. What is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy
Wide local excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy
Simple vulvectomy without lymph node assessment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy

 

Explanation:

This patient's tumor size, invasion depth, and clinically negative nodes place her in stage IB.

 

Treatment of Tumor Stages of Vulval Cancer

Stage 1

  

1a (Option B)
  • Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin is performed for the probable cure.

1b
  • Radical resection of the primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy (LAD).
  • Central lesion: B/L LAD
  • Lateral lesion (> 2 cm from midline): U/L LAD.

Stage II
  • Radical vulvectomy + B/L LAD
  • Positive LN involvement in HPE - Must do pelvic LAD or pelvic LN radiotherapy.

Stage III
  • Radical partial or total vulvectomy and either SLNB or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.
  • Postoperative adjuvant radiation (4000-5000 Rads over 5 weeks) directed to both the groins and the pelvis.

Stage IV
  • Treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy: 5-FU, mitomycin C
  • Other agents used are Methotrexate, bleomycin, and trastuzumab.

 

Option C: Chemoradiation therapy alone is typically reserved for patients who cannot undergo surgery due to medical comorbidities or in cases where the tumor is not resectable and incase of distant metastasis

 

Option D: Simple vulvectomy alone does not adequately address the potential risk of lymph node metastasis. SLNB is important to rule out microscopic lymph node involvement, even in the early stages.

questions.text: A 68 Y/o female presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a noticeable lump in the vulvar region. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. the growth is limited to the vulva with no clinically palpable groin nodes. Imaging studies reveal no distant metastasis. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the 5-year survival rate for this patient?

choices.text: The 5-year survival rate is less than 30%
The 5-year survival rate is between 30% and 50%
The 5-year survival rate is between 50% and 70%
The 5-year survival rate is between 70% and 90%

questions.solution:
Answer: D) The 5-year survival rate is between 70% and 90%

 

Explanation:

Based on the above scenario, the patient is likely to have stage I vulvar squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Prognosis of vulvar cancer:

 

FIGO staging

5-year survival rate

Stage I & II (no lymphatic involvement)

70-90% (Option D)

Stage III (inguinofemoral lymph node involvement)

30-50% (Option B)

Stage IV (tumor with regional spread)

≤30% (Option A)

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with a history of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) presents with a mass in the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina
Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's age and history of DES exposure make this the most likely diagnosis.
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is closely linked to in-utero DES exposure.
  • Most DES-exposed patients with vaginal cancer were born between 1951 and 1956 when the drug was most frequently prescribed.

 

Vaginal Carcinoma

Etiology
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection; HPV 16 is most common.
  • In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES)
  • Chronic vaginal irritation or inflammation.
  • Previous cervical or vulvar cancer.
  • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
 

General population

DES-exposed women during pregnancy

Most Common Site

Upper third of the vagina, particularly the posterior wall.

Upper third of the vagina, particularly the anterior wall.

Most Common Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A)

Clear cell adenocarcinoma (Option B)

Clinical Features
  • Painless vaginal bleeding and abnormal discharge (M/C symptom)
  • Post-coital bleeding
  • Vaginal mass or ulcer
  • Pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse)

 

Option C: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma of the vagina is the most common malignancy of the vagina in infants and children, typically occurring in girls younger than 5 years old.

 

Option D: Leiomyosarcoma of the vagina is the most common type of vaginal sarcoma in adults, usually affecting women older than 40 years old.

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with a history of abnormal Pap test results. Colposcopy reveals a well-defined, white lesion in the upper third of the vagina. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN). What is the most likely stage of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stage 0

 

Explanation:

  • This patient's biopsy confirms VAIN, which is considered a pre-invasive lesion.
  • Pre-invasive lesions are classified as Stage 0, as they haven't invaded the surrounding tissue.

 

Staging of Vaginal Carcinoma

Stage

Characteristics

0

Carcinoma in situ, Intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN) (Option A)

I

Cancer is limited to the vaginal wall.

II

Cancer has spread to the subvaginal tissue but not to the pelvic wall. (Option B)

III

Cancer has spread to the pelvic wall and/or regional lymph nodes. (Option C)

IVA

Tumor invades bladder and/or rectal mucosa and/or direct extension beyond the true pelvis. (Option D)

IVB

Spread to distant organs.

 

Management of VAIN:

  • Observation: For low-grade lesions, especially in younger or postmenopausal women without symptoms. Involves repeat colposcopy and biopsy.
  • Wide Excision: Involves surgically removing the VAIN lesion along with a margin of healthy tissue. This serves as a definitive treatment and is often the preferred approach for high-grade VAIN.
  • Laser ablation: For localized high-grade lesions.
  • Topical Treatments: Application of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) cream, Imiquimod (5%), Dinitrochlorobenzene for high-grade lesions.

Follow-up: Regular surveillance with Pap smears and colposcopy to monitor for progression or recurrence.

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents with intermittent vaginal bleeding for the past 3 months with a past history of hysterectomy. Pelvic examination reveals a small 2 cm ulcerative growth in the upper posterior vaginal wall. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Further radiological metastatic workup showed that the cancer was limited to the vaginal wall. What would be an appropriate treatment strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radical vaginectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation aligns with Stage I vaginal cancer, characterized by the carcinoma being limited to the vaginal wall.
  • For Stage I disease, especially involving the upper posterior vagina (MC site of vaginal cancer) surgery is the preferred treatment if negative surgical margins can be achieved. Surgery performed is a radical vaginectomy & pelvic lymphadenectomy. If the uterus is in-situ, it is removed as a radical hysterectomy specimen. 
  • In addition, patients with recto-vaginal or vesicovaginal fistula (Stage IV) may be candidates for primary pelvic exenteration.

 

  • All other stages & those where surgery is not feasible radiation therapy is the treatment. Small superficial lesions may be treated with intracavitary brachytherapy alone. Larger thicker lesions should be first treated by external bean radiotherapy to decrease tumor volume & to treat the regional pelvic nodes, followed by bracytherapy.
  • Concurrent chemotherapy is also considered with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with SCC arising from the Bartholin gland following a biopsy after she presented with complaints of unilateral swelling in the vulvar area. Which of the following is an indication for bartholin gland biopsy?

choices.text: Solid mass arising from Bartholin gland

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Women over 40 years of age who have recurrent Bartholin cysts/abscesses or solid masses should have a biopsy performed.

 

Bartholin gland carcinoma
  • Maybe adenocarcinomas, SCC, or transitional cell carcinoma

Clinical features
  • Painless vulval mass
  • Perineal pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Spreads to ischiorectal fossa and pelvic nodes

Investigations
  • MRI
  • Bartholin biopsy: Indications include,
    • Woman over 40 years
    • Recurrent cyst/abscess
    • All solid masses

Treatment
  • Radical vulvectomy + Ipsilateral/bilateral groin dissection
  • Pre/post-operative chemoradiation

questions.text: A 66 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent pain, and a visible lump in her vulvar region. On examination, the gynecologist notes a raised lesion on the labia majora. A biopsy is performed, and the results are indicative of malignancy. Which of the following is the most common subtype of vulvar cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common subtype of vulvar carcinoma followed by malignant melanoma.

 

Classification of Vulvar carcinoma:

questions.text: A 72y/o woman presents with a vulvar lesion for the past 6 months. She reports persistent pruritus and occasional bleeding from the lesion. On examination, a 2 cm ulcerated lesion is found on the labia majora. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which lymph nodes are MOST commonly involved in the lymphatic drainage and spread of vulvar carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inguinofemoral lymph nodes

 

Explanation:

  • This patient was diagnosed with Squamous cell carcinoma of vulva.
  • Inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most common and superficial inguinal node is the Sentinel lymph node drainage for vulva.
  • Lymph node involvement is crucial for prognosis and surgical planning.

 

Lymphatic drainage of the vulva

Location of Lesion

Primary Drainage Site

Notes

Lateral Vulva

Ipsilateral superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Vulvar lymphatics do not cross the labiocrural folds.

Within 2 cm of Midline

Either superficial inguinal lymph node group.

Lesions in this area may spread to either side.

Clitoris and Upper Labia

Drain directly to the deep femoral nodes.

  

Entire Vulva (Distal Third of Vagina)

Superficial inguinal node group

Lymph travels to the deep femoral lymphatics and then through the node of Cloquet to the pelvic lymph nodes (meaning distant metastasis). (Option C)

Option A: The para-aortic lymph nodes are primarily involved in the drainage of abdominal organs, such as the kidneys and intestines.

Option D: The axillary lymph nodes are responsible for the upper limbs, chest, and breast drainage.

questions.text: A 68 Y/o woman presents with a 6-month history of persistent vulvar itching and burning. She reports noticing a red, velvety rash on her vulva that occasionally oozes. On physical examination, there is an erythematous and eczematous lesion on the vulva. Biopsy of the lesion reveals large cells with abundant cytoplasm in epithelium. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Paget's disease of the vulva

 

Explanation:

The 68 year old postmenopausal woman with red velvety, eczematous lesions on the vulva most likely have paget’s disease of vulva.

Paget’s disease of vulva
  • Most common extramammary Paget’s disease, originating from apocrine glands and proliferates into the epithelium.
  • 10-20% of people are associated with invasive Paget’s disease or adenocarcinoma of vulva.
  • Symptoms: Erythematous chronic skin lesions associated with pruritus, burning and pain. Multifocal well-demarcated velvety erythematous plaques, more commonly seen on labia majora.
  • Biopsy of the lesion shows paget’s cells (large cells with abundant cytoplasm) in the epithelium

Treatment

  • Non-invasive disease: lesions are resected by wide local excision with 1-2 cm margin.
  • Invasive disease: Radical partial vulvectomy with/without inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.

 

Option A: Lichen sclerosus is a chronic dermatological condition seen in prepubertal girls and postmenopausal women. Porcelain white plaques are seen in lichen sclerosus.

 

Option C: Vulvar candidiasis is a gynecological infection commonly seen in immunosuppressed or diabetic patients. Curdy white discharge is usually seen.


Option D: Bowen’s disease, a precancerous condition that may progress into invasive squamous cell carcinoma, is characterized by tender, erythematous epidermal lesion with induration.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a non-healing lesion on her vulva. On PE, a thickened, whitish plaque and ulceration are noted on the labia majora. Histopathology reveals atypical squamous cells confined to the epithelium with marked basal atypia and abnormal keratinisation as shown below. Which of the following is the patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Differentiated VIN

 

Explanation:

VIN commonly presents as areas of leukoplakia. Sometimes the lesions can be pigmented due to the presence of melanin. The predominant symptom is pruritus. The diagnosis is made by careful inspection of the vulva followed by biopsies of suspicious lesion. Vulvoscopy after application of 5% acetic acid to the skin & introitus can be helpful to identify subtle lesions & the most abnormal areas to biopsy. Some clinicians prefer to use toluidine blue to identify vulvar lesions.

Classification of Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (Vulvar Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion):

 

Normal vulva

  • Lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Vulvar LSIL

Previously VIN 1, flat condyloma or HPV effect
  • Seen in younger women, premenopausal  (option B)
  • Etiology: HPV effect, mostly HPV 6 & 11. Smoking & immunosuppression are risk factors
  • Flat lesions, multifocal can progress to condyloma
  • Self limited, not precancerous

Histology:

 

 

  • Mild atypical cells in the lower third of epithelium
  • Koilocytes in the upper layer

Vulval HSIL

Previously, Usual type VIN;

VIN2 or VIN3

 
  • Formerly called usual VIN (option A&C)
  • Seen in younger women, premenopausal
  • Etiology: HPV related, mostly HPV 16. Immunosuppression & smoking are risk factors.
  • Multifocal disease, lesions appear bulky.
  • Precursor lesion for warty/basaloid squamous cell cancer.

Histology:

 

 

  • Atypical squamous cells in all layers of epithelium
  • Extensive parakeratosis
  • Koilocytic changes in the upper layer.

Differentiated VIN
  • Seen in older, postmenopausal women (option D)
  • Etiology: related to long standing Lichen Sclerosus 
  • Unicentric and unifocal disease
  • Precursor lesion for keratinizing squamous cell cancer

Histology:

 

 

  • Abnormal keratinization
  • Cytological atypia confined to the basal layer

 

Treatment:

 

Vulvar LSIL
  • Self-limited condition.
  • Not treated unless symptomatic.

Vulvar HSIL and differentiated VIN
  • Precancerous conditions.
  • All lesions should be treated.
  • Treatment options:
  • Wide local excision
  • Laser ablation
  • Topical 5-FU or imiquimod
